How To BRAND Your COMPANY. Discover the secrets of effective branding with our three-step method designed to transform your business. First, we dive into DISCOVERY, where we get to know your business inside and out. Who are your target audience? What do they need, want, and desire? What sets you apart from the competition? We analyze your brand‚Äôs unique traits and how you want to be perceived by your customers. Next, we move to STRATEGY. Here, we craft your ideal customer persona and define your brand positioning. We give your brand a personality and a compelling story that resonates with your audience. We also create a competitive landscape, taglines, and three moodboards to help visualize your brand‚Äôs potential look and feel. This phase ensures that every aspect of your brand is aligned to attract and engage your target customers. Finally, we bring it all together in the DESIGN phase. This is where your brand comes to life, showcasing its best attributes in a cohesive and attractive manner. With our in-depth approach, you‚Äôre not just getting a logo or a website; you‚Äôre getting a comprehensive strategy that defines how your brand looks, talks, and acts. Improve your UI design and web design by mastering typography! Stop making common typography mistakes in your web designs. Here are some tips to enhance your font pairings and hierarchy: - Don‚Äôt just browse your font list. Check out http://fontshare.com for great free fonts. - Use Typewolf to find visual pairings from real-world examples. - Don‚Äôt rely solely on font size to create hierarchy. Adjust font weight on paragraphs, increase leading, and ensure good contrast on smaller fonts. - Limit centered text to two lines. Always left-align your text for readability. Avoid right alignment. - Headers don‚Äôt need to be heavy to stand out. Find the right balance and adjust kerning carefully for a clean look. #uidesign #uiux #webdesign #productdesign created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound

Mastering spacing is the secret that elevates a product designer from good to great. It's a crucial UI design skill that elevates the user experience. Why? Because our ultimate goal is to help users to navigate their desired goals effortlessly--why IA is so important. Here's a peek into my playbook: I leverage spacing (think padding & margins) to boost readability and scanability. It's all about creating harmony‚Äîtighter margins for related elements to signal connection, and generous padding (around 20 to 30 pixels) to delineate distinct sections. Horizontal spacing should be more than vertical to help create natural blocks within sections. Remember these are starting points and the true art lies in knowing when to stick to these guidelines and when it's okay to break it for the sake of a better more functional ui design. #uiux #productdesign #uidesigner #uxdesigner #appdesign  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Let‚Äôs make the perfect portfolio! After reviewing hundreds of award winning agencies and portfolio sites, I think this is the best above the fold hero section in web design.  Start with clear and concise header that tells people what you do and who do you that for. It‚Äôs so easy to bloviate or try to be unique with forced copywriting. The best are simple, around 10 words, and help frame the type of work visitors are about to see below. Speaking of work, let‚Äôs talk about the things that can get web visitors to scroll: the preview! By simply showing a graphic of your design work peaking through the bottom, you can make the hero more interesting and get users to scroll. It‚Äôs easy to throw on a ‚Äúscroll‚Äù label at the bottom, but don‚Äôt tell me to scroll. Show me what I‚Äôm scrolling to. Let me know what you think and if you‚Äôll start implementing this on your agency/portfolio site! #webdesign #portfolio #webagency #portfoliodesign  created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound

If you‚Äôre trying to better understand UI/UX Design, there‚Äôs no better place to start than reading The Design of Everyday Things by Don Norman. There‚Äôs a lot to this book, but the biggest things I took away from it was the importance of Affordances and Feedback. At the end of the day, most of your job as a designer is to create interaction points, rank them by importance to the user persona, and then get the ideal user persona to click on those buttons. So the best way to get users to click on buttons in your UX Design is add affordances. Affordances are signifiers that guide users on what interaction points will do. It‚Äôs easy to forget how important this is because designers are often biased towards the context that users will have. When you‚Äôve been working on the same product for months, things that are natural to you are complete unknowns to the users. While some users will be okay clicking around until they figure it out, it‚Äôs best to streamline the user flow by showing tooltips, subheadings, and learn more buttons. This will make it so power users can ignore them while newcomers will gain confidence. Now, once a user taps the buttons or fills out a form, they need to know that it worked. If you don‚Äôt offer that to users, it makes even power users feel nervous that the desired action didn‚Äôt happen. This can make our users feel like they don‚Äôt know how to use the product and rather than learn how to use it, they‚Äôll just stop using it. That‚Äôs why we need to add as much feedback as we can to let users know that things have happened or when things are moving slow, that there is still progress being made. If you‚Äôre interested in UX Design you really need to check out this book! #uxdesign #uiux #uxdesigner #appdesign #webdesign #productdesigner  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Here‚Äôs how to make a color palette for your ui/ux design in just a few easy steps. It all starts with a single brand color. You‚Äôll take your brand color, and add an overlay on top of it. You‚Äôll set the overlay to white and black and then have different opacities on it to create a palette. This is my go to process for product design because in app design, you really don‚Äôt want to overdo it with color. Most of your app should be black and white with splashes of color and secondary highlights to distinguish different sections in the layout. This means that to use color to bring out a better information architecture, you only need a black color, a white color, a border color, and a secondary highlight. Making your blacks and whites tinted to the brand color will take your designs to the next level! #appdesign #uiux #colordesign  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

You want to show brand logos on your landing page. This is the easiest and most attractive way to do that. First, stop going to Google images and searching by brand. Instead, use an app called BrandFetch. Pull directly from their website or use their Figma plugin. Next, open the PNG or SVG versions of your logos in Photoshop. Open up Layer Styles, and set a Color Overlay to white or black. This most certainly goes against the brand usage guidelines of many brands, but I‚Äôm not a lawyer, just a janky ass designer. Choose a maximum width to be used for your logos. I like to choose a max width AND height for the container of the logo, and then resize the logo within. One thing I‚Äôll add is when choosing these dimensions, I multiply them by 2 or 3.  So if my max-width of the logo on the web page needs to be 200pixels, I‚Äôll save the image with a max-width of 4 or 600 pixels. This allows me to a crispier resolution of the image on retina displays without sacrificing too much page load performance. And as a side note, you don‚Äôt have to name your image files with 2x or 3x anymore, you simply have to make sure the HTML img tag uses a srcset parameter with the correct value, like 2x or 3x. Put the logos on a contrasting background, set opacity to 80% and boom. You have yourself a good looking AND performant brand logo section on your landing page. If you want to add an extra detail, set a mouse hover effect on the logo images to transform the scale of the logo by 1.2 and opacity to 100%. I like the little details. #uxdesign #uidesign #webdesign #tutorials #designertom created by DesignerTom with DesignerTom‚Äôs original sound

Here's how to make the ui design for bento box grids! Bento box grids are super trendy right now. In both product design and web design, the Bento grid is doing wonders organizing lots of relevant information. The big challenge with bento grids is going overboard with the content. If you don't strategically prioritize certain boxes in the grid, the ui design may look nice, but the ux design and readability can fall apart. The best way to be strategic here is to lower the amount of information per box. Aim for 1 header and 2 small lines of text at most. Add a graphic, but especially in the smaller boxes, have the graphic be simple and express ONE idea visually. The next step is to try to guide the user's eyes with text by putting the text in a z reading pattern. #uiux #uidesign #webdesign #bentobox  created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound

Replying to @dr.fvn Making a unique design portfolio starts with what makes your design approach unique. If you‚Äôve been designing for a while, you will have a design process, design approach, and personal perspective that comes from the way you look at the world. That unique perspective is what will make hiring managers and potential clients want to work with you. So start with that perspective, then write case studies from tell that story. Then the rest of your design portfolio should focus on making them feel confident that your experience can translate into designing a product for their specific needs. #design #portfolio #productdesign #uiux  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

In UI design, it‚Äôs often little details that make all the difference. A good shadow can make or break a design. The biggest thing that I focus on when adding shadows to my designs is that you need to make users feel the shadow, but not think about the shadow. The best way to do that is make them really soft. Shadows in UI need to follow lighting rules as they happen in the real world. An element that sits above another should cast shadow on the elements behind. And in my opinion, shadows should only be on the most important elements which are really ‚Äúin your face‚Äù meaning those elements are much closer to you in 3d space. With that, I can make really soft bubbly UI by adding a shadow that is between 10 and 20 pixels Y, 20 to 40 pixels of blur, and a really light opacity between 8% and 12%. Those guidelines of shadow will get you through a lot of shadow blocks! #uidesign #uidesigner #uiux #designtutorials  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Design is not art--design is action. That's why UX design is all about harnessing user desires and moving users down the user flow. The way you direct users is through making better interaction points. Buttons should have some padding to give them attention. That padding should be wider than it is tall so that users who are scanning can easily find the interaction points. You can also make your ui design easier to scan by giving the buttons distinct colors that stand out. You can train users to look for a specific color on the page to increase the speed to finding the interaction points. Just, don't over-use primary color buttons. It should be one primary action per section or page and the other buttons should either have a border and be a ghost button or have a passive color that doesn't stand out so much. This is such a focused topic in ui design, but it's one of the most important parts of design because this is how the user navigates through the app. Being intentional with your interaction point design is a huge part! #uidesign #appdesign #uiux #uxdesign  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Replying to @moreira_creates This is how I use spacing in my UI Designs. The focus of my spacing (padding & margins) is always around readability and scanability. Create natural groupings by adding less margins between grouped elements. Create sections by creating airy padding of around 20 to 30 pixels between them. And horizontal spacing should usually be more than vertical because it creates natural blocks within sections and groups. These are general guidelines that I use, but depending on the instance you can break these rules as needed. #uiux #uidesigner #productdesigner #uxdesigner #appdesign  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Replying to @soul_william Here‚Äôs how I approach my font sizes when working with Typography in my ui/ux designs. You have to use font sizes to your advantage to guide the user‚Äôs eye towards key areas. You do this by using information architecture! Information Architecture is much more than just font sizing, but typography plays a huge part in IA design. Information Architecture has us letting the user scan to confirm they‚Äôre on the right page, then scan to find the right section of content they‚Äôre looking for, then scan to find the right piece of content inside that section. This zoom-tier is how I approach all of my designs from the type I use to the colors and shadow I add. With this, we want to make page headers the largest, then section headers a little smaller, then group headers smaller than that. Some people use the fibonacci sequence or the golden ratio to map their header sizes accordingly. I‚Äôm not that particular, though it ends up similar at about 1.5x the size of the next tier. I usually start from section headers as those are the most common for scanning. Once I have that set, I work in increments of 2 or 4 points at a time until I end up with roughly 34+ points or higher in page headers, 16-26 points on sections, and 14-18pt on group headers. From there, I generally keep paragraphs around the same size as group headers or 2 to 4 points smaller and then use a thinner/lighter font weight to keep things easy to read. #informationarchitecture #iadesign #fontsize #typography #uxdesign #uiux  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

Replying to @chukwuma Ubani When you‚Äôre first starting starting in UI & UX Design, it‚Äôs overwhelming deciding what to learn and when. I think you shouldn't focus on UX Design too early--you can learn that as you build your UI Design skills. You should, instead, start by learning the basics of a design tool like Figma, then diving into design fundamentals by recreating a new design every day. On the side, you should stdy typography and information architecture, but don‚Äôt try to learn all of UI design at once. Take the studies slowly or you'll lose interest taking on too many things. And you'll need the time because on top of the daily UI recreation, you should also design at least 10 full app designs from start to finish. The work will be really rough for a while, and that's okay. Understand that everyone started out this way, but passion helped them through the difficult learning process. #uiux #uidesigner #uxdesigner #appdesigner #designtutorials #figmadesign  created by Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan with Nolan Perkins ‚ñí RadNolan‚Äôs original sound

When you‚Äôre designing a website, the most important thing you need to design for is visitor intent. Before you begin the UI/UX design stage, you need to map this out. Everyone is coming to the website at different points in the buyer‚Äôs journey. Some want to buy now, others are trying to learn more, and the rest don‚Äôt even know why they‚Äôre there. When you‚Äôre designing a hero section, you need to know what point in the buyers journey the page is for and where else they may go next. You can do this by taking the site map, then labeling each page with the likelihood of buying now. Then you need to map out the connections to other pages. At that point, you know exactly what type of content you need to present and how you‚Äôll present it. #webdesigner #webdesign #websitedesign #websitetips  created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound

So you're kicking off a web design project But before you can do any ui ux design You need to hop on a call and ask your client these questions First, what is the primary goal of the website? Are they looking for meetings booked? Demos requested? Email captures? Each requires different messaging Also, make sure to ask how people will find the website Will they be coming from ads or networking events? Will they know about the product or services at all? And to that extent, you need to understand what the visitor might be searching for before they're ready to close. With that, you'll be ready for design Before you start designing, you need to know all the context of the project. The best way to align on context is to understand what success looks like to your web design client. The way to nail that down is by asking 3 detailed questions: ‚ÄúWhat is a close?‚Äù Looking for downloads versus form signups or email captures over webinar wait listers all require different messaging. The messaging will affect the story you‚Äôre trying to tell through your web design. ‚ÄúWhat context will visitors have?‚Äù If someone meets your client in real life at a networking event, they‚Äôll be coming to the website with very different context than someone coming from an ad. This will affect the information architecture you need to approach your design with. Finally, ‚ÄúWhat information will they need before they‚Äôre ready to close?‚Äù Needing pricing info is great, but how about competitor comparisons? Maybe details on the services is not as important as understanding the culture that the company has. These things will really set you up for success for your web design clients because it will lead to more conversions! #webdesign #webdesigner #designclients created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound

Finding the right typography in your ui design is not always easy. Here's what I do when designing websites: I go to either Google Fonts or Adobe Typekit and find a cool font. Both have great filtering tools which allow you to filter by weight, type of font, and even variable fonts! Another great way to find great fonts is go on inspiration websites, look for cool fonts, and then use the Fonts Ninja plugin. This allows you to find out exactly what font is being used on the website. From there, you simply search for the font on Typewolf to find similar fonts that are free to use, and also great pairings that go with it! #typography #findingfonts #designtips #webdesigner #uidesigner  created by RadWebDesigns with RadWebDesigns‚Äôs original sound
